315201 China cZhejiang Institute of Tianjin University, Ningbo, Zhejiang 315201, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1,4-butanediol has attracted much attention and Lyondell method is a competitive production technology due to its wide range of feedstock sources, in which the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts is an essential step. By combining Density Functional Theory and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, the formation mechanisms and pathways of byproducts acetone and propanal in the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts were systematically investigated. Most species tend to be adsorbed on Pd atoms, which is consistent with that Pd atoms are main active sites. Acetone is obtained by the hydrogenation of CH3COCH2*, which comes from the oxidation and then dehydrogenation of propylene. Propanal is produced by the hydrogenation of CH3CHCHO*, which can be formed by the dehydrogenation and then oxidation of propylene or the oxidation and then dehydrogenation of propylene. Compared with acetone, propanal is more difficult to form and its formation reactions have higher Gibbs activation energy. This work provides theoretical guidance for the better modification of catalysts and the reduction of byproducts acetone and propanal on microscopic and mesoscopic scales. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propylene PdCu catalysts Mechanisms Acetone Propanal Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Acetoxylation is a significant organic synthesis reaction, in which the C − H functionalization provides new opportunities for the construction of CO bond, 1-7 to make olefins transform into acetoxy compounds. An important application is the production of vinyl acetate monomer by the acetoxylation of ethylene. 8-16 Besides, acetoxylation of propylene with acetic acid can produce allyl acetate, which is an important organic synthesis intermediate, widely used in the field of medicine, agriculture, surfactant, resin, etc., and has broad market prospects. 17-21 In recent years, with the increasing demand for the degradable plastic, as an important raw material of poly (butylene succinate) (PBS) and poly (butyleneadipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT), which are degradable plastic with excellent properties, 1,4-Butanediol (BDO) has a good market situation. 22-24 Farther more, propylene currently has the problem of overcapacity. The research and development of the production of allyl acetate using propylene, oxygen and acetic acid as raw materials and further production of BDO can not only meet the current market demand for degradable plastic, but also alleviate the situation of propylene overcapacity. 18 Darien now uses this method to produce BDO, the basic principle of which is shown in Scheme 1 . There are two processes for the preparation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene: liquid phase method and gas phase method. For the liquid phase method, the selectivity of is low and more byproducts such as propenyl acetate, isopropenyl acetate, acetone and CO2 will be produced. 25-29 In addition, there are other problems such as higher pressure (1–7MPaG), strong corrosiveness of the medium, complex catalyst system with frequent regeneration (PdCl2 or Pd(OCOCH3)2), which limit the industrial application of liquid phase method. The gas phase method is performed by the reaction of propylene, acetic acid and oxygen with the temperature of 413.15–453.15 K and the pressure of 0.5–1MPaG in the tubular fixed-bed reactor filled with Pd based catalyst and it is currently the mainstream process for the production of allyl acetate, which is similar to the process of ethylene acetoxylation to produce vinyl acetate. Further studies have been conducted on the mechanism of acetoxylation of ethylene over Pd based catalysts. Van Helden et al. first described the mechanism of the homogeneous process (liquid phase method): the olefin is coordinated to the Pd salt catalysts; next a CO bond is formed by the coupling of the acetoxy species to the olefin; then the β-H elimination reaction occurs to form vinyl acetate; and finally, the catalyst is regenerated by a redox system. 30 However, the homogeneous process has been almost completely replaced by heterogeneous process catalyzed by Pd metal catalyst, whose mechanisms mainly consist of S-mechanism and M-mechanism. 31 , 32 In 1971, Samanos et al. put forth a hypothesis suggesting that acetic acid adsorbed on the surface of Pd based catalysts would be dehydrogenated, forming acetoxy species, which would then undergo a coupling reaction with ethylene, resulting in the formation of intermediate CH2CH2OCOCH3*. Finally, the β-H elimination reaction of CH2CH2OCOCH3* would yield the desired product of vinyl acetate. 33 In contrast, Moiseev et al. proposed that ethylene adsorbed on the catalyst surface initially undergoes dehydrogenation to form vinyl, which then couples with acetoxy species adsorbed on the catalyst surface to generate vinyl acetate. 31 Later, a comprehensive comparative DFT study on the mechanism of acetoxylation of ethylene was performed to reveal that Moiseev mechanism is preferred on PdAu(100) surface. 34 For the acetoxylation of propylene, there were several studies examining the reaction mechanism. Kunugi et al. studied the acetoxylation of olefins on supported Pd metal and Pd salt catalysts in the gas phase, and proposed two catalytic mechanisms on the catalysts of Pd metal and Pd salts, respectively, as shown in Figure S1a and S1b. 35 Two decades later, in 1993, Minachev et al. investigated the reaction of propylene, acetic acid and oxygen using Pd-zeolite as catalyst, and discussed the formation mechanism of allyl acetate, as shown in Figure S1c. 36 Besides, Minachev hypothesized a different mechanism of the acetoxylation of propylene using PdCu catalysts in the gas phase method, that is, propylene was first oxidized to allyl alcohol, followed by its esterification by acetic acid. 37 However, it was found that both O atoms in the reaction product of acetoxylation of propylene were derived from acetic acid, and the reaction scheme they proposed was actually same as the mechanism in Figure S1c. In 2005, referring to the reaction mechanism of ethylene acetoxylation to vinyl acetate by Nakamura, 31 Chen et al. speculated the mechanism of propylene acetoxylation, including two steps, which are oxygen-assisted dehydrogenation first and then the coupling of acetyloxy and allyl, as shown in Figure S1d. 38 In general, the palladium and its salts or complexes are the most effective catalysts for acetoxylation. Whereas, the addition of the second metal compounds to the palladium catalyst usually improves the selectivity of target products, such as copper and iron. 39 With the improvement and development of the process of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate, most of catalysts are the bimetallic Palladium-Copper (PdCu) catalysts, 27 , 40-49 which can not only improve the selectivity of allyl acetate, but also reduces the economic cost of using palladium in industrial processes. 50 Besides, the formation mechanism of CO2 in the production of allyl acetate from propylene on PdCu(111) surface has been studied in our previous study. 51 However, acetone and propanal, as the byproducts of partial oxidation of propylene, may exit in the system of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate. 27 , 28 , 35 , 36 , 38 And there is a dearth of comprehensive and methodical investigation into the genesis of these two byproducts, which have limited the reduction of byproducts formation and the modification of catalyst to a great extent. Density functional theory (DFT) has become a pivotal research instrument in the area of physical chemistry, offering substantial insights into the chemical reaction mechanisms. 52-54 And kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) is a statistical simulation method guided by probabilistic statistical theory, which can elucidate the interactions between all elementary processes in catalytic processes. 55-57 Furthermore, the combination of DFT and kMC has also been widely employed for the investigation of the reaction mechanism underlying catalytic processes. 58-61 In this study, Density Functional Theory (DFT) and kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) simulations were performed to investigated the formation mechanisms and the dominant formation pathways of acetone and propanal in the process of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts. Firstly, the reaction networks and surface model of PdCu catalysts were constructed. Then the adsorption properties of related species and all elementary reactions of the reaction networks were studied to reveal the reaction mechanisms by DFT calculations. Based on this, related kinetic parameters were obtained and used for kMC simulations to clarify dominant formation pathways of acetone and propanal. It's hoped that our work will provide theoretical guidance for the better modification of catalysts and the reduction of byproducts acetone and propanal on microscopic and mesoscopic scales. 2 Computational details 2.1 Density functional theory calculations DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) with the exchange-correlation functional of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) 62 within the projector-augmented-wave (PAW) method. 63 With the convergence test performed, the cutoff energy for expanding the wave function into plane wave basis functions was set to 500 eV. A dipole correction was applied in the direction normal for slab calculations. 64 The relaxation of the electronic degrees of freedom stopped if the total energy change and the band-structure-energy change between two steps were both smaller than 10–5 eV and the ionic relaxation loop was stopped when the norms of all the forces were smaller than 0.03 eV/Å. DFT-D3 method with Becke-Johnson damping function was used for the van der Waals correction. 65 , 66 The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was used to calculate the transition states, which were confirmed by observing one single imaginary frequency. 67 The Gibbs free energy is calculated by eq (1): (1) G = E + Z P E + H − T S Where E represents the electronic energy, ZPE represents the zero-point energy correction, H represents the thermal correction to enthalpy, T represents the temperature, S represents the entropy and the PV contribution to translation for adsorbed molecules is neglected. 68 In this work, the T was set to 433.15 K, which is the typical temperature of the process of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate. The Gibbs reaction energy ( G r ) and activation energy ( G a ) were calculated by eq (2) and eq (3), respectively. (2) G r = G F S − G I S (3) G a = G T S − G I S Where G I S , G T S and G F S are the Gibbs free energy of related initial states (IS), transition states (TS) and final sates (FS), respectively. 2.2 Kinetic Monte Carlo simulations Kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) is a variant of Monte Carlo method which is a statistical simulation method under the guidance of probability statistics theory. VSSM (Variable Step Size Method) and Lattice-gas Model were used for the kMC simulation. 69 The two-dimensional periodic model with 128 × 128 lattice points was used to represent the catalyst surface. According to the collision theory, the adsorption rate constants is calculated from eq (4). 70 (4) k ads = σ 1 P A site 2 π m k B T Where P is the partial pressure (Pa) of adsorbate in the gas phase; A site is the area of an adsorption site; σ 1 is the adhesion coefficient, which is set to 1; 71 m is the mass (kg) of an adsorbate molecule; k B is Boltzmann constant; T is the temperature (K). The reaction rate constant is calculated by Transition State Theory (TST). 72 (5) k = ν exp ( − E a R T ) Where ν is pre-exponential factor; R is the ideal gas constant; T is the reaction temperature (K) and E a is the energy difference between transition state and initial state corrected by ZPE correction. The pre-exponential factor ν is calculated as follows. 73 , 74 (6) ν = ∏ i = 1 3 n ν i I S ∏ i = 1 3 n − 1 ν i T S Where ν i I S is the vibrational frequency of initial state; ν i T S is the vibrational frequency of transition state (excluding the imaginary frequency); n is the number of atoms of the reactant (adsorbate). The rate constant of gas desorption is defined as: (7) k des = Q vib , gas Q vib , ads Q rot , gas k B 2 T 2 h 3 A site ( 2 π m i ) exp ( − E des k B T ) Where Q vib,gas and Q vib,ads are the vibrational partition functions of gaseous and adsorbed molecules; Q rot,gas is the rotational partition function of gaseous molecules; h is Planck constant; mi is the mass of gas molecules (kg). E des is the desorption barrier, which is numerically equal to adsorption energy. Q vib,gas is defined as eq (8) (linear molecule) and eq (9) (nonlinear molecule). (8) Q vib , gas = ∏ i = 1 3 n − 5 e − h v i 2 k B T 1 − e − h v i k B T (9) Q vib , gas = ∏ i = 1 3 n − 6 e − h v i 2 k B T 1 − e − h v i k B T Where v i is the vibrational frequency of gaseous molecule; n is the number of atoms of gaseous molecule. Q vib,ads is defined as: 75 (10) Q vib , ads = ∏ i = 1 3 n e − h v i 2 k B T 1 − e − h v i k B T Q rot,gas is defined as eq (11) (linear molecule) and eq (12) (nonlinear molecule). 70 (11) Q rot , gas = 1 σ T θ rot (12) Q rot , gas = π σ ( T 3 θ rot , A θ rot , B θ rot , C ) 1 / 2 Where σ is a dimensionless symmetric number; θ rot, θ rot,A, θ rot,B and θ rot,C are rotational characteristic temperatures (K), which can be obtained from literatures. 70 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface model It's generally acknowledged that PdCu alloys have fcc crystal features and (111) facet is the most stable surface for the fcc crystal. 76-78 What's more, the top atomic layer of PdCu is rich in Cu, while the near surface region is rich in Pd. 79 , 80 The Pd atoms in the surface layer are surrounded by Cu atoms and tends to be dispersed as isolated monomers. 79 , 81-83 More importantly, in the process of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate, the content of Pd in the catalyst is higher than that of Cu, and the molar ratio of Pd to Cu is usually about 3. 49 , 84 , 85 Therefore, we aimed to construct the surface model of PdCu(111) with Cu-rich in surface layer and Pd-rich in bulk phase, and the molar ratio of Pd to Cu is close to the value of related patents. Goulas et al. investigated the synergistic effects in PdCu catalysts in oxygenate coupling reactions and the results showed that the catalyst composed of 3:1 (Pd:Cu) had higher catalytic activity and meanwhile, the surface of the catalyst is rich in Cu. 86 The oxidative coupling catalyzed by Pd catalysts plays an important role in organic synthesis, which is an effective method to construct CC bond, CN bond and CO bond. For the acetoxylation of propylene, the C atom of methyl of propylene and O atom of acetoxy group of acetic acid are coupling and the ratio of Pd to Cu of the catalyst is similar. 86 Consequently, the similar surface model was constructed in this work, which is shown in Fig. 1 (a). The k-point of 11 × 11 × 11 was used for the optimization of Pd and Pd3Cu lattice cells. The Pd3Cu lattice cell is similar to pure Pd and Cu lattice cells in that it is a face centered cubic crystal. 87 The bulk lattice constants of Pd are 3.935 Å, which is in good agreement with the experimental value of 3.890 Å and calculated value of 3.989 Å. 86 , 88 The bulk lattice constants of PdCu are 3.867 Å, which is consistent with the calculated value of 3.891 Å. 86 , 88 In order to examine the stability of the Pd3Cu alloy, the formation energy (E f) was calculated according to the following equation: 89 (13) E f = E alloy − N A E A ( bulk ) − N B E B ( bulk ) Where E alloy is the energy of the alloy cell; N i and E i ( bulk ) are the number of i atoms in the alloy cell and the energy of one bulk-phase atom of mono-metal i. A stable alloy needs to fulfill the condition that the formation energy is negative. In this work, the formation energy of Pd3Cu cell is −0.304 eV, which shows that the Pd3Cu alloy can exist stably. The Pd3Cu cell is then cleaved, a 4 × 6 supercell is created and the associated atoms in the top atomic layer are replaced and optimized to obtain a PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface model, which is consistent with Pd atoms in the surface layer being surrounded by Cu atoms and dispersed as isolated monomers. In addition, for the surface model, the vacuum layer of 20 Å was used and the k-point was set to 2 × 4 × 1 with the convergence test performed. The uppermost two layers of atoms of the surface model were allowed to relax while the bottom layers of atoms were restricted. Furthermore, Bader charge was calculated for the surface model, and the charge distribution of the top atomic layer is shown in Fig. 1(b). It can be found that on top atomic layer, Pd atoms all have the charge of −0.228 |e| and Cu atoms have the charge of about 0.123 |e|, which indicates that electron transfer has taken place between Pd and Cu atoms, increasing the electron density of Pd atoms. This result is consistent with the difference in electronegativity between Pd and Cu atoms. The two-dimensional charge density map of the top atomic layer is depicted in Fig. 1(c), which provides a more visual representation of the charge difference between the Pd and Cu atoms. For the transition metals Pd and Cu, the electronic nature of the d-band is more important in contributing to chemisorption properties and catalytic properties than the s-band and p-band electrons. The d-band center model proposed by Nørskov is widely used for surface reactions catalyzed by transition metals. 90 The partial density of states of d band (d-PDOS) of Pd and Cu atoms on top atomic layer of the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface model are shown in Fig. 1(d), where the d-band centers and Fermi level are marked. The closer the d-band center is to the Fermi level, the higher the energy of the d-band electrons, the higher the catalytic activity of the metal surface and the stronger the interaction between the adsorbed species and the metal catalyst surface. The d-band center of Pd atom is −1.413 eV, while the d-band center of Cu atom is −1.632 eV. The d-band center of Pd atom is closer to Fermi level, so that Pd atoms have stronger interaction with adsorbed species and are more active on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface, which can also explain the preference of adsorbed species to adsorb at Pd atoms in the later section. 3.2 Adsorption properties of related species The adsorption properties of propylene, oxygen, acetone and propanal on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface were investigated. The adsorption energies and electron transfer between these species and the surface model are shown in Table 1 . The most stable adsorption configurations are illustrated in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from Fig. 2, these species tend to be adsorbed on Pd atoms, including Pd top sites, Pd-Cu bridge sites and Pd-Cu fcc sites, which is consistent with that Pd atoms are main active sites in the acetoxylation of propylene. The results of our previous work show that ethylene is more easily adsorbed on Pd top site on PdAu(100) surface and the two carbon atoms of ethylene are bound to one Pd atom. 91 Xu et al. studied the active sites of Pd nanocrystals for propyne semihydrogenation and their DFT calculation showed that propylene was adsorbed on Pd octahedrons and cubes in a π adsorption mode, in which the two carbon atoms with sp 2 hybridization are adsorbed on the same Pd atom. 92 Chu et al. performed DFT calculations to investigate the behavior of propylene binding on a single Pd atom (C3H6-Pd). 93 Besides, there are some research shows that propylene adsorbs preferentially on Pt(111) and Pd3Ag(111) in a di-σ adsorption mode where the double bond bridge two next neighbour Pd or Pt atoms on the surface. 94-96 Consequently, the π and di-σ adsorption modes of propylene on the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface were studied. These adsorption configurations and their adsorption energy are shown in Figure S2. It is worth noting that after optimization, the configuration of di-σ adsorption mode would be transformed into the π adsorption mode, that is, on PdCu3/Pd3Cu (111) surface, the configurations of di-σ adsorption mode are extremely unstable, which can be attributed to the difference in the electronegativity between Pd and Cu atoms. For π adsorption mode, the configuration of propylene adsorbed on Pd atom has larger adsorption energy and is more stable than that of Cu atom. Then, additional calculation was conducted to investigated the effect of different methyl orientations on the stability of adsorption configurations. The results showed that the difference in the adsorption energy of the adsorption configurations with different methyl orientations does not exceed 0.02 eV, so the methyl orientation has almost no effect on the adsorption stability. On PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface, O2 has a variety of adsorption configurations, as shown in Figure S3, among which the most stable adsorption configuration of O2 is “CuCu-PdCu-Bri1” with the adsorption energy of −1.270 eV, whose two oxygen atoms are adsorbed on the Pd-Cu bridge site and Cu-Cu bridge site, respectively. For acetone, the O atom is adsorbed on the Cu-Cu bridge site, while the C atom with sp 2 hybridization is adsorbed on the Pd top site, forming the most stable adsorption configuration, with the adsorption energy of −0.993 eV. Propanal is also adsorbed on PdCu3/Pd3Cu (111) surface via its O atom and the C atom with sp 2 hybridization, which form bonds with the Cu and Pd atoms to obtain the preferred adsorption configuration with the adsorption energy of −0.918 eV. Table 1 also lists the electron transfer between adsorbed species and PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface. The results demonstrated that propylene has the largest adsorption energy among the four species, while exhibiting minimal electron transfer with the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface. This observation led to the hypothesis that there is no direct relationship between electron transfer and adsorption energy. We further calculated the Bader charge of each atom of these species before and after adsorption on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface, as shown in Table S1. Meanwhile, the charge density difference map was plotted in Fig. 3 to visually express the charge transfer before and after adsorption of related species. There is almost no electron transfer between propylene and the surface model, which may be caused by the equilibrium of electron density between the C = C bond of propylene and Pd atom on the catalyst surface. O2 gains the most electrons via its two oxygen atoms from Pd and Cu atoms of the catalyst surface. For acetone and propanal, they all obtain some electron through their O atoms and C atoms with sp2 hybridization. 3.3 DFT calculations for the formation mechanism of acetone and propanal in the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface 3.3.1 Mechanism for the formation of acetone on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface Acetone is the byproduct from the partial oxidation of propylene during the production of allyl acetate. The reaction network 97-99 is illustrated in Fig. 4 , consisting of 20 elementary reactions, whose Gibbs reaction energy ( G r ) and activation energy ( G a ) are listed in Table S2. The dissociation reaction of O2 (R1) on the catalyst surface was first investigated to produce activated oxygen atoms. R1 is a strong exothermic reaction, which releases the energy of 1.91 eV and the Gibbs activation energy is only 0.08 eV. With the progress of the reaction, the two oxygen atoms gradually move away until they are located on the Pd-Cu fcc site and Pd-Cu hcp site, respectively. Starting from propylene, acetone can be obtained by adding an oxygen atom, removing and adding a hydrogen atom, respectively. R2 is the combination reaction of propylene with H* to form the intermediate CH3CHCH3* adsorbed at Pd top site, whose Gibbs reaction energy is 0.54 eV and Gibbs activation energy is 0.92 eV. CH3CHCH3* may then undergo the oxidation reactions, including R3 and R4. R3 is the formation reaction of CH3CHOCH3* through the coupling of CH3CHCH3* and O*, with the Gibbs activation energy of 1.04 eV and Gibbs reaction energy of −0.60 eV. R4 is the reaction of OH* binding to CH3CHCH3* to form CH3CHOHCH3*, which may undergo the direct dehydrogenation reaction (R5) and O-assisted dehydrogenation reaction (R6) to form the same product as R3. Compared with R3, R4 needs to overcome higher energy barrier of 1.77 eV, while the next O-assisted dehydrogenation of reaction (R6) only has the activation energy of 0.14 eV. Finally, acetone is obtained by the direct dehydrogenation reaction (R7) and O-assisted dehydrogenation reaction (R8) of CH3CHOCH3*, with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.94 and 0.76 eV, respectively. The configurations of initial states, transition states and final states for R1-R8 are shown in Figure S4 and the Gibbs free energy landscape is shown as red lines in Fig. 5 . Moreover, propylene can first undergo oxidation reaction, combining with O* to form the intermediate CH3CHOCH2*, with the same Gibbs activation energy as R2, 0.92 eV. CH3CHOCH2* is adsorbed on the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface via its O atom located at Pd-Cu fcc site and the C atom of CH2 group located at Pd top site, and there are four pathways to form acetone by CH3CHOCH2*. R10 is the hydrogenation reaction of CH3CHOCH2* to CH3CHOCH3*, which need to overcome the energy barrier of 0.30 eV and then acetone is produced by R7/R8. R11 is the hydrogen transfer reaction of CH3CHOCH2*, leading directly to acetone. As the reaction proceeds, the H atom of CHO group is shifted to the C atom of CH2 group and in the transition state configuration, the H atom is located between the two C atoms. R11 has a relatively high Gibbs activation energy of 1.15 eV. Apart from the oxidation and dehydrogenation reactions, the dehydrogenation of CH3CHOCH2* was also researched. R12 and R13 are the direct dehydrogenation and O-assisted dehydrogenation reactions to produce CH3COCH2*, with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.37 and 0.41 eV, respectively. CH3COCH2* is adsorbed on the catalyst surface through its C = C bond and O atom and then acetone is formed when one H atom attacks the C atom of CH2 group, which has the Gibbs activation energy of 0.69 eV (R17). Interestingly, we also found that CH3CHOCH2* can generate more stable intermediate CH3COHCH2* via hydrogen transfer reaction with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.49 eV. Then the direct dehydrogenation reaction (R15) and O-assisted dehydrogenation reaction (R16) of CH3COHCH2* may occur the form the same intermediate as R12/R13, with the energy barrier of 0.59 and 0.02 eV. The Gibbs free energy landscape of R9-R17 is shown as blue lines in Fig. 5. The dehydrogenation of propylene to form the intermediate CH3CCH2* was also studied. The formation reactions of CH3CCH2* are endothermic, including direct dehydrogenation reaction (R18) and O-assisted dehydrogenation reaction (R19), whose Gibbs activation energies are 1.14 and 1.15 eV, and need to adsorb the energy of 1.02 and 0.37 eV, respectively. CH3CCH2* is adsorbed on the Pd top site through its middle carbon atom, which is in an unsaturated state. Then, due to the high amount of O2 in the reaction system for the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate and the ease with which O2 dissociation reaction can take place, the oxidation of CH3CCH2* to CH3COCH2* (R20) was considered, with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.52 eV and the Gibbs reaction energy of −1.36 eV. Finally, the coupling of H* and CH3COCH2* (R17) may take place to form acetone. The Gibbs free energy landscape of R18-R20 is shown as green lines in Fig. 5. Analyzing the results of the calculations, when propylene is first hydrogenated to produce the intermediate CH3CHCH3*, the dominant pathway for further generating acetone is CH3CHCH2* → CH3CHCH3* → CH3CHOCH3* → CH3COCH3* (R2 → R3 → R8) and the combination reaction of CH3CHCH3* and O* has the highest Gibbs activation energy of 1.04 eV. When propylene is first oxidized to form the intermediate CH3CHOCH2*, except for the hydrogen transfer reaction (R11), other reactions are all possible and compete with each other to finally produce acetone. In this pathway, the oxidation of propylene to CH3CHOCH2* has the highest activation energy of 0.92 eV. For the last pathway, the activation energy of the dehydrogenation reaction of propylene to CH3CCH2* (R18) is as high as 1.14 eV, indicating that it is difficult to gain an advantage in the competition with R2 and R9. 3.3.2 Mechanism for the formation of propanal on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface Propanal is also the byproduct of the partial oxidation of propylene during the production of allyl acetate. The reaction network 100 is illustrated in Fig. 6 , of which elementary reactions were listed in Table S3. The configurations of initial states, transition states and final states for each elementary reaction are shown in Figure S5. The Gibbs free energy landscape for the formation of byproduct propanal on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface is shown in Fig. 7 . Before investigating the partial oxidation of propylene to form propanal, we studied the combination reaction of O* and H* to form OH* (R32). The reaction is strongly exothermic, requiring only 0.13 eV of activation energy to be overcome, and can release the energy of 0.87 eV. Given the high content of O* in the reaction system and the ease of O* and H* combination reaction, oxidation or dehydrogenation reactions, rather than hydrogenation reactions, are the first to be considered in the studies on the formation reactions of propanal. R21 and R22 are the direct and O-assisted dehydrogenation reactions of propylene to produce the intermediate CH3CHCH*, which is adsorbed on the Pd-Cu fcc site via its C atom that has lost one H atom. The two reactions are both endothermic, which need to overcome the energy barrier of 1.16 and 1.26 eV, and absorb the energies of 0.55 and 0.05 eV, respectively. R23 is the hydrogenation reaction of CH3CHCH* to CH3CH2CH*, with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.61 eV and Gibbs reaction energy of 0.34 eV. The intermediate CH3CH2CH* has a similar adsorption configuration to CH3CHCH* at the Pd-Cu fcc site. R24 is the combination reaction of CH3CH2CH* with O* to produce propanal, whose Gibbs activation energy is 0.51 eV and Gibbs reaction energy is −0.91 eV. Unlike R23 and R24, CH3CHCH* can also be oxidized (R25) and then hydrogenated (R31) to generate propanal. R25 is a strongly exothermic reaction, which need to overcome the energy barrier of 0.73 eV and release the energy of 0.96 eV and the final state CH3CHCHO* is adsorbed on the Cu top site via its O atom and Pd top site via its C atom in the CH group. Finally, propanal is obtained by the hydrogenation reaction of CH3CHCHO*, which has the Gibbs activation energy of 0.40 eV and Gibbs reaction energy of 0.23 eV. Additionally, the hydrogen transfer reaction of propylene to CH3CH2CH* (R26) was studied, which has the same product as R23, and the Gibbs activation energy is 1.05 eV, which is slightly lower than that of R21 and R22. The Gibbs free energy landscape of R21-R26 is shown as red lines in Fig. 7. Next, we considered the pathway in which propylene first combines with O* to undergo the oxidation reaction. R27 is the formation reaction of CH3CHCH2O* by the combination of propylene and O*, with the Gibbs activation energy of 1.24 eV and Gibbs reaction energy of 0.62 eV. CH3CHCH2O* is adsorbed on the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface via its O atom located at Pd-Cu fcc site and its C atom in CH group located at Pd top site. R28 is the hydrogen transfer reaction of CH3CHCH2O* leading to propanal, with the Gibbs activation energy of 1.15 eV, which is more difficult to occur than the direct dehydrogenation reaction (R29) of CH3CHCH2O* to CH3CHCHO*, with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.34 eV. Besides, CH3CHCHO* can be formed by the O-assisted dehydrogenation reaction of CH3CHCH2O*, which has much high energy barrier of 1.88 eV and will release the energy of 1.34 eV. Finally, the C atom in CH group of CH3CHCHO* will be attacked by H* atom to form propanal, whose Gibbs activation energy is 0.40 eV. The Gibbs free energy landscape of R27-R31 is shown as blue lines in Fig. 7. Lastly, the formation reactions of H2O are investigated, consists of the combination of OH* with H* (R33) and the disproportionation of OH* (R34) with the Gibbs activation energy of 0.48 eV and 0.41 eV, and the Gibbs reaction energy of −0.10 and 0.27 eV, respectively. The configurations of initial states, transition states and final states for R33 and R34 are shown in Figure S6. 3.4 The kMC simulations for the formation of acetone and propanal in the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface In this section, based on the data derived in Section 3.3, kMC simulations of the reaction network for the generation of acetone and propanal were carried out to gain further insight into the possible partial oxidation of propylene on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface. The dominant pathways for the formation of acetone and propanal were analyzed in conjunction with the results of the kMC simulations. The PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface model in kMC simulation is illustrated in Fig. 8 , which corresponds to the surface model in DFT calculation with the same active sites. All species of the partial oxidation of propylene to acetone and propanal are defined in the lattice-gas model, including CH3CHCH2*, O2*, O*, H*, OH*, CH3COCH2*, CH3CHOCH3*, CH3COCH3*, CH3CHCHO* and CH3CH2CHO*, etc. The reaction networks for kMC simulation consists of the adsorption and desorption of reactants and products, surface reactions and surface diffusion. Surface diffusion mainly considers the diffusion of O* and OH*, which are the main intermediate species on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface. The elementary processes and related kinetic parameters are shown in Table S5. For the elementary reactions, symbol ‘↔’ indicates that the positive and reverse reactions are both considered in the simulation. E a,f and E a,r represent the activation energy of the positive reaction and reverse reaction, respectively; ν 0,f and ν 0,r are the pre-exponential factor of the positive reaction and reverse reaction, respectively. The simulated conditions are set as the industrial operation conditions for the preparation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene, the specific temperature is 433.15 K, the pressure is 0.90 MPa, and the mole fraction of propylene and oxygen is 0.41 and 0.06, respectively. The kMC simulation time was 1 s, at which point the surface coverage of each species reached stability and the reaction system reached equilibrium. The surface coverage of each species and the reaction frequency of each elementary reaction in the reaction network for the formation of acetone and propanal when the reaction system reaches equilibrium are analyzed. 3.4.1 The dominant pathway for the formation of acetone The surface coverage of related species in kMC simulation are listed in Table 2 and species not mentioned in the table have a coverage of almost 0. It can be found that O* has the highest surface coverage, followed by O2* and propylene, which are all the reactants for the partial oxidation of propylene to acetone. Besides, it is noteworthy that only the intermediate CH3COCH2* was detected with a surface coverage of 0.0219, which is the key specie for the formation of acetone. The forward and reverse reaction frequencies of each elementary process for the formation of acetone on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface when the system reaches steady state in the kMC simulation are shown in Table 3 . The frequency an elementary process actually occurs is calculated by eq (14) and for the elementary process not listed, the forward and reverse reaction frequencies are both 0. (14) N actual = N forward − N reversible Where N actual represents the actual reaction frequency of an elementary process; N forward represents the forward reaction frequency and N reversible represents the reverse reaction frequency. The frequencies of elementary processes for the formation of acetone show that on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface, there is an absolute predominance of propylene combining with O* (R9) to react to form CH3CHOCH2*, which is also consistent with the highest surface coverage of O*. Then, 75.64 % of CH3CHOCH2* was directly dehydrogenated (R12) to generate the key intermediate specie CH3COCH2* and 21.35 % of CH3CHOCH2* underwent the O-assisted dehydrogenation (R13) to produce the key intermediate specie CH3COCH2*. Additionally, the remaining 3.02 % of CH3CHOCH2* produces CH3COCH2* through hydrogen transfer reaction (R14) and direct dehydrogenation reaction (R15). It is worth noting that all CH3CHOCH2* has reacted to form CH3COCH2* via R12-R16. Finally, the hydrogenation reaction of CH3COCH2* (R17) occurs to produce acetone, which all underwent the process of desorption. And the conversion of CH3COCH2* was 7.95%. The reaction network for the formation of acetone combined with the actual reaction frequency of each elementary process is shown in Fig. 9 (a), in which the actual reaction frequencies are represented as red numbers. As shown in Fig. 9(a), the dominant pathway for the formation of acetone can be readily discerned, which is illustrated in Fig. 9(b). 3.4.2 The dominant pathway for the formation of propanal The surface coverage of related species in kMC simulation are listed in Table 4 and species not mentioned in the table have a coverage of almost 0. Different from the formation of acetone, there were two main intermediates, CH3CHCH* and CH3CHCHO*, with the surface coverage of 0.00117 and 0.00108, which were both lower than that of CH3COCH2*. The forward and reverse reaction frequencies of each elementary process for the formation of propanal on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface when the system reaches steady state in the kMC simulation are shown in Table 5 . From the data in Table 5, it can be seen that propylene can generate CH3CHCH2O* through oxidation reaction (R27) and CH3CHCH* through dehydrogenation reactions (R21 and R22) in the ratio of 1.42. CH3CHCH* mainly reacts with O* (R25) to form the key intermediate specie CH3CHCHO*, with the conversion of 16.19 %. Besides, a negligible quantity of CH3CHCH* will be transformed into CH3CH2CH* through hydrogenation reaction (R23). However, the specie CH3CH2CH* will subsequently engage in the hydrogen transfer reaction (the reverse reaction of R26), ultimately yielding propylene. For the intermediate CH3CHCH2O*, it all undergoes the direct dehydrogenation reaction (R29) to the key intermediate specie CH3CHCHO*. Finally, propanal is formed by the hydrogenation reaction (R31) of CH3CHCHO* with the conversion of 51.48 %. And 89.74 % of propanal comes from the pathway: CH3CHCH2* → CH3CHCH2O* → CH3CHCHO* → CH3CH2CHO*, while 10.25% of propanal comes from the pathway: CH3CHCH2* → CH3CHCH* → CH3CHCHO* → CH3CH2CHO*. The reaction network for the formation of propanal combined with the actual reaction frequency of each elementary process is shown in Fig. 10 (a), in which the actual reaction frequencies are represented as red numbers. According to Fig. 10(a), the dominant pathway for the formation of propanal can be easily obtained as shown in Fig. 10(b). 4 Conclusion In this work, the formation mechanisms and dominant formation pathways of acetone and propanal in the process of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts were systematically investigated by DFT calculations and kMC simulations on microscopic and mesoscopic scales. Specifically, the adsorption properties of related species, mechanisms for the formation of acetone and propanal on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface were revealed, then the dominant formation pathways of acetone and propanal were analyzed. The main conclusions are as follows. (1) Proplene, oxygen, acetone and propanal all tend to be adsorbed on Pd atoms, including Pd top sites, Pd-Cu bridge sites and Pd-Cu fcc sites, which is consistent with that Pd atoms are main active sites in the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate. Cu atoms mainly play the role of dispersing Pd atoms in the catalyst. When the loading amount of the catalyst is constant, the catalytic activity can be improved by increasing the dispersion of Pd atoms. (2) There is no direct relationship between electron transfer and adsorption energy. There is almost no electron transfer between propylene and the surface model, which may be caused by the equilibrium of electron density between the C = C bond of propylene and Pd atom on the catalyst surface. Oxygen gains the most electrons via its two O atoms from Pd and Cu atoms of the catalyst surface. For acetone and propanal, they all obtain some electron through their O atoms and C atoms with sp2 hybridization. (3) Acetone is a byproduct of partial oxidation of propylene on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface. Propylene first forms CH3CHOCH2* by oxidation reaction, then most of CH3CHOCH2* undergoes dehydrogenation reaction to produce the key intermediate specie CH3COCH2*, and finally acetone is obtained by the hydrogenation reaction of CH3COCH2* and desorbed to gas phase product. The specific dominant pathway is as follows: CH3CHCH2* → CH3CHOCH2* → (CH3COHCH2*) → CH3COCH2* → CH3COCH3*, in which, the first step, the combination reaction of propylene with O* to CH3CHOCH2* has the highest Gibbs activation energy of 0.92 eV. (4) Propanal is also produced by the partial oxidation of propylene, which is obtained by two main formation pathways. Propylene can generate CH3CHCH2O* through oxidation reaction and CH3CHCH* through dehydrogenation reactions in the ratio of 1.42. Then CH3CHCH2O* and CH3CHCH* both form the key intermediate specie CH3CHCHO*. Finally, propanal is formed by the hydrogenation reaction of CH3CHCHO*, of which 89.75 % comes from the pathway of “CH3CHCH2* → CH3CHCH2O* → CH3CHCHO* → CH3CH2CHO*”, while 10.25% comes from the pathway of “CH3CHCH2* → CH3CHCH* → CH3CHCHO* → CH3CH2CHO*”. Compared with acetone, propanal is more difficult to form on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface and its formation reactions have higher Gibbs activation energy. coredata.dc:description: 1,4-butanediol has attracted much attention and Lyondell method is a competitive production technology due to its wide range of feedstock sources, in which the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts is an essential step. By combining Density Functional Theory and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, the formation mechanisms and pathways of byproducts acetone and propanal in the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts were systematically investigated. Most species tend to be adsorbed on Pd atoms, which is consistent with that Pd atoms are main active sites. Acetone is obtained by the hydrogenation of CH3COCH2*, which comes from the oxidation and then dehydrogenation of propylene. Propanal is produced by the hydrogenation of CH3CHCHO*, which can be formed by the dehydrogenation and then oxidation of propylene or the oxidation and then dehydrogenation of propylene. Compared with acetone, propanal is more difficult to form and its formation reactions have higher Gibbs activation energy. This work provides theoretical guidance for the better modification of catalysts and the reduction of byproducts acetone and propanal on microscopic and mesoscopic scales.
